text: The legend reads: OCTOBER 10th

Darkness.  Headlights bounce off thick sheets of RAIN.  6 gallon Esso OIL TRUCK barrels over wet studded pavement, heading towards Manhattan.  It's going fast.  Too fast. Up ahead...at the BASE OF THE BRIDGE: A large reflective sign - lit up by arc lights: MEN AT WO There are TWO WORK CREWS, several hundred feet apart. THE FIRST CREW is CON ED.  A corrugated vacuum tube feeds into an open MANHOLE.  A WORKER drops into the hole. THE SECOND CREW is CONSTRUCTION.  They're at the apron of bridge securing lumber supports for the roadbed. It's late and the men are tired.  A mistake is made.  A F LIFT loaded with LUMBER fails to negotiate a turn...whack into an abutment... spilling its load onto the roadway. Bad timing, because right now that Esso OIL TRUCK hits th OFF RAMP.  Not a lot of time for the driver to react to a roadway spewed with lumber. He does his best.  Slams the brakes, spins the wheel, hit the horn, but it doesn't matter: 18 wheels skid across th blacktop - spitting thick smoke and burnt rubber, lifting the slick pavement...twisting...flipping...hemorrhaging o from its ruptured tanks...grinding its way towards... MEN AT WORK.  Seconds to react as an 80,000 pound juggern of death plows through parked cars like paper...crushing Con Ed equipment...lurching to a halt on top of the MANHO
TWO FIRE TRUCKS (1000 Gallon Pumper and Mack Tiller Ladde pull into the street.

SIRENS wail, cherry tops spin. FRANK SULLIVAN, 40, is strapped into an open-air jumper s A real life hard charger, Frank is the kind of iron's man fire fighters want coming in after them, should they get caught in harm's way.  Kind-hearted and hard-fisted, he h the grace and courage of a man living by his convictions. Across from Frank sits GRAHAM GIBSON, 20.  A good-looking African-American, "Gib" is a Fire Fighter Fourth Grade, a tank man... and one nervous probie. Through a window into the CAB, we SEE LT. BUTCH FOSTER, 5 on a walkie-talkie.  A beefy old pro who's been through m fires than he can remember. A walkie-talkie sits in a cradle between Frank and Gibson
(through walkie-talkie) ...oil all over the street.  Cracked water and gas mains.  Four companies coming in...
Butch's voice continues as Frank calmly absorbs the information, while at the same time.
(re: rain) Oh, man.  Hope it ain't like this in Baltimore tomorrow.
Baltimore?
The game, Graham.  The Series?
Gibson taps his wristwatch.
Oh, yeah.  Damn.  My watch is busted.
Hey, Rookie.  Be cool.  Just stay with me.  This is what we do.
(still tapping his watch) I seem nervous, huh?
Frank laughs.  Gibson grins, relaxes a bit.  Frank checks ROLEX DIVER'S WATCH.  Multiple SIRENS fill the dawn.
It's 5:30, Gib.
(through walkie talkie) ...two Con Ed men trapped in an underground electrical conductor vault.
Frank's eyes harden.  His game face sets up.

A tableau of impending danger.  Thick black OIL bleeds fr teh truck onto the street...pouring underneath the rig... into the MANHOLE. POLICE urgently cordon off the area, evacuating the worke EMERGENCY PERSONNEL deal with the badly injured TRUCK DRI Firemen wedge sandbags between the hull of the truck and three-quarters covered manhole -- trying to divert the oi away from the underground vault. FIRE COMMANDER O'CONNELL yells at his men to finish the j and get the hell away. The BIG TRUCKS ARRIVE.  PUMPER ENGINE and Frank's LADDER TRUCK -- rapidly guided into position by men on the groun Frank, Gibson, Butch and the rest of the unit are on the ground instantly and ready for orders.  They are looking nightmare ready to happen.  Frank takes in everything. FIRE COMMANDER O'CONNELL and a CON ED SUPERVISOR approach
(deep irony) A fun one.
Yep.
We got high voltage cables ripped loose in the underground.  They hit water, that fault's gonna arc.
Frank looks at the tanker over the manhole.  There is now nobody around it.
Why haven't they killed the juice?
Switches are shorted out.
You're shitting me!
Wish I was.  Oldest part of the system down there.  We're on it, but it's gonna take awhile.
We gotta go underground.  Get those guys out, now.
We tried.  Bulkhead door's rusted shut. Won't budge.
The block is being evacuated.  I don't want anybody... including our boys...within fifty yards of that tanker...it's a fucking bomb.

Frank has been staring at the capsized rig. Butch knows what he's thinking.  But it's too late.  Fran gone...slogging through the oozing oil to the hull of the tanker.  He kneels over the three-quarters covered manhol using a flashlight to peer into the darkness below.  Spar from the loose cables spit off flashes of light as the ca hiss and slap against the ceiling and walls of the vault.
This is the Fire Department.  Frank Sullivan.  You guys okay?
Please man, you gotta get us out of here...
That's exactly what we're gonna do.
And Frank is up, heading for his truck, signaling Gibson.
(yells to Con Ed Supervisor) How do we get to the vault door?
There's a manhole at Canal and Bowery.
Forget it, Frank.  No way you reach those men in time.
Frank grabs a "halaghan claw tool" and a walkie-talkie. Gibson nervously picks out two helmet lights...and they a off and running.
(yelling back) I can do it, Butch.  Me and my 'tank man' here.
(to all, and into walkie) Start spraying down the street.  Let me know when we are fully evacuated.
Frank uses the "adz" to rip open the heavy manhole cover.

Frank and Gibson descend into the tunnel, strap lights on their leather helmets to illuminate the damp darkness.  T race down the subterranean passage.  The stench is thick. Butch's voice suddenly booms out of the walkie-talkie:
(via walkie) Frank, you hear me?  Frank?
(into walkie) Yeah, Butch?
(via walkie) The gas level is getting serious. The underground's combustible - it could flashover.  I want you to abort!  Now! Get the hell out of there!
Frank picks up the pace.  Charges ahead.  Guy's got balls
(into walkie) Frank.  We gotta go back.  Frank...
(calling back to him) Stay with me, Gib.  We're gonna do this.
(charging after him) I should'a been a fucking mailman.

Frank reaches the rusted 'submarine-like' VAULT DOOR.  Po on the door... a faint response.  He goes to work on it w the halaghan tool.  Gibson arrives...pretty rattled.  Fra gives him a wink and a smile.  It's gonna be okay.
(via walkie) Frank, where are you?

Frank digs down, suddenly the DOOR GIVES WAY Oil and water rush from the VAULT, pouring over Frank and Gibson, foaming into the tunnel.  But the door is mounted three feet off the ground.  There is still three feet of and water trapped inside.  And the smell of gas is now overwhelming...
(into walkie) We're in, Butch.

Frank probes the dark vault with the FLASHLIGHT BLADE. Through smoke we see TWO MEN huddled in the corner, trapp by three loose 'HOT' CABLES - WHIPPING AROUND THE TINY VA LIKE AN ELECTRIC HYDRA.  Con Ed Worker #2 shivers, ankle broken, leaning on older Con Ed Worker #1.
Time to go home, fellas.
Gibson sprays the room, clearing out most of the smoke. Frank steps into the vault.
Careful.  If the hot end of those cables hits you, it'll conduct to the water and we're all fired.

Frank drops to his knees, ducking under the cables, shuff to center of the vault.  Places his hands at opposite end the halaghan tool, hoping for the cables to pass directly over his head.  A hairy beat, then... Frank jackknifes out of the water, ramming the halaghan i the ceiling.  It worked.  The teeth on the "claw-end" and spike on the "adz-end" are embedded into the concrete -- STAPLING THE CABLES TO THE CEILING.  Make that balls of steel.
Go, Gibby!  Everybody move it.

Gibson and Con Ed worker #1 help injured Worker #2 out of vault.  Frank checks to make sure they've cleared the vau and lets go of the tool. Frank jumps into the tunnel, hoists the injured worker ov his back and races back down the tunnel.
(to Gibson) Haul ass, that claw ain't gonna hold for long... (into walkie) Take cover -- she's gonna flash!
O'Connell and the few remaining cops & firemen run for it

Frank, Gibson and the Con Ed men scramble towards the manhole.  Butch and another fireman are waiting up top. help the men -- who are covered in oil and slime -- up on the street.  And then they all tear away from the manhole...around a corner... collapsing on the pavement against a building.

The vault ignites, the tunnel "FLASHBACKS" -- a towering geyser of FLAMES AND DIRT ERUPTING out of the manhole fro which Frank has just escaped. In the distance, FLAMES erupt out of the other manhole...engulfing the OIL TRUCK...blowing it into a mil pieces. Through the INFERNO at the base of the Manhattan Bridge, Frank can see that no one is hurt.  His eyes glistening w adrenaline and relief, he sits back against the building throws an arm around Gibson.
You did good, Gib.  Real good.
Frank looks over at the hyperventilating Butch and smiles
Elvis has left the building.

Inside the tunnel.  Dark.  Moving fast.  Flashes of LIGHT bounce off the shiny tile walls.  The deep throated ROAR '67 HARLEY battles with Martha & the Vandellas' HEAT WAVE We are with Frank, wearing a leather jacket with the insi of his fire-fighting unit emblazoned on it, and a New Yor Mets BASEBALL CAP pulled down tight, as he rockets his chopper through traffic, out of the tunnel, and up into..

CREDIT MONTAGE begins as Frank cruises home.  It has STOP RAINING.  Frank passes by billboards and other evidence o the approaching METS/BALTIMORE ORIOLES World Series. He circles a LITTLE LEAGUE ball field waving to some OLDSTERS.

Frank glides the Harley alongside his house.  A feisty DALMATIAN PUPPY ELVIS barks his welcome from behind a fen Feeling fatigued, Frank dismounts and enters teh backyard playing for a moment with Elvis while he uprights a TRAIN BICYCLE, tidies up BASEBALL EQUIPMENT, and glances up at HAM RADIO ANTENNA secured to the roof, before entering through a backdoor.  There is a sense of routine to all t

The kitchen is empty.  Breakfast dishes in the sink.  Fra flips on the RADIO.  It plays out under the rest of the MONTAGE as coverage of the oil truck crash blends into ot news stories. A note on the refrigerator reads: 8:15.  Hey, Bud.  I'm o to work. Johnny's at school.  Elvis is fed.  I luvs you. Setting a grapefruit and a slice of toast on the table, F glances at the Daily News.  But his eyes are tired, he st off into space...letting go.
A radio in the bedroom is tuned to sports news.  Frank so in a hot bath.  He looks like he might fall asleep - and does. CREDITS END.

CRASH!  A SOFTBALL BLOWS through the window from the BACKYARD, landing on the rug next to the bed.  Frank bolt awake, staring at the busted window. He checks the clock.  It is 5:15.  He steps to the broken window.  SEVERAL SMALL BOYS scurry from the yard.  Two others, JOHNNY SULLIVAN and GORDO HERSCH, both 6, stand frozen in place.  Elvis tears in circles around them.  Al very quiet.  Then, from somewhere beyond the bedroom door HEAR The Beatles' BACK IN THE THE USSR...
JULIA SULLIVAN, 32, is rockin' out, chopping vegetables.
(singing to song) ...show me 'round the smokey mountains way down south...

Adorable, sweet and strong.  Strawberry blonde hair, sapp eyes, soft earthy vibe.  A beauty. Frank, wearing FDNY sweats, moves into the kitchen flippi the softball from hand to hand.  Julia turns to him and r her eyes at the sight of the ball.  Say no more.
Hey, bud.
Hey, bud.
Without breaking stride, he gives her a smack on the lips steps to the screen door to the back porch.
Johnny stands nervously outside the door.  Elvis sits at side.  Gordo watches from the safety of his own porch nex door.  Frank opens the screen door, casts a stern look do at his son.
Looks like two weeks worth of allowance, Chief.
I know.  Sorry, Dad.
Glad to hear that.
And Frank drops the softball into Johnny's mitt, closes t screen door and turns back into the kitchen.  Johnny turn away into the yard.
With a shrug, and sharing a kids will be kids smile with Julia, he grabs a cold Rheingold from the refrigerator an heads into...
...past a CONSOLE TELEVISION, to the HI-FI
(calling to Julia) How about a little of the King?
(from kitchen) Well, why not a little of the King?
Julia crosses her eyes, as if she could stop him.  Frank moves to change records.
Suddenly, a PAN of spaghetti sauce bubbles over.
Damn.
You alright?
I think I ruined the sauce...again.
As Elvis' SUSPICIOUS MINDS plays, Frank steps back in, mo up behind Julia, and takes her in his arms.
What's the matter, Jules?  Trouble workin' an eight hour shift, watching the kid and whipping up a little bolognese?
You didn't marry Donna Reed.
I'd go with you and Chinese take-out over her any time.
And he turns her around and they start to dance as Frank sings along to Elvis, badly.
(singing lyrics) Caught in a trap, I can't walk out, because I love you too much b-b-baby.
We follow the music as it drifts out into the YARD where can SEE Johnny and Gordo looking in at the weirdness.
How was your tour?
The usual.
Frank spots Johnny and Gordo staring at them.  He winks a the boys and swings Julia into a Fred Astaire dip.
(loaded) Butch called.
Did he?
He did.
It was under control, Bud.  Butchy's just getting tight in his old age.
Nothing wrong with old age, Frank...long as you get there.
With a laugh, Frank drops Julia into another dip.  As the music fades, we...

CLOSE ON: BICYCLE TRAINING WHEELS lying on the sidewalk. Johnny is precariously perched on his fire engine red BICYCLE.  He wears a police badge and a whistle around hi neck.  Frank stands beside him, holding on to the bike se We're on a quiet side street next to house.  It's the las light of the day. Hold on Johnny's eyes...fear.
Okay, start pedaling.
Daddy put the wheels back on.  I'm gonna fall.
Don't think about falling, just keep pedaling.
Daddy, I'm scared.
C'mon, Chief, show some guts.
Johnny takes a gulp of air, doesn't want to disappoint hi father, nods okay. He starts pedaling.  Slowly moving forward.  Frank holds to the seat.  Frank's still hanging on - jogging along si
I'm gonna let go!

Frank let's go.  Johnny's pumping those little six year-o legs, but he starts to wobble out of control -- CRASH! Johnny starts to cry, quickly gets up and runs back to th house.  Julia comes out of the kitchen door.  Johnny runs into her arms.
Don't quit on me now, Chief.
Johnny tears himself from Julia's arms, runs inside. Frustrated, Frank lights up another cigarette.
Don't be so tough on him Frank, he's six years old. (softer) He just needs to know you're right there behind him.
Frank takes a deep drag on the butt.  Steps onto the YARD stares up at the starry night.
JOHNNY'S POV: Frank standing in the yard, wishing on a st Johnny looks up at the sky and makes a wish of his own.

Countless points of light blaze across vast blackness.  A luminous blue sphere floats peacefully below EARTH.  We a 22,000 miles away in geosynchronous orbit. MULTI-BILLION DOLLAR PIECE OF HARDWARE drifts into and fi the frame - 1 1960's COMMUNICATION SATELLITE, NASA & HUGH logos affixed to the glistening aluminum hull. All is still for some moments.  But then a sound disturbs quiet of the cosmos.  It's coming from the horizon.  From something that looks like a hole in the fabric of space. Bright streaks of starlight swirl around into that hole. And slowly the satellite begins drifting towards it - pul in by some invisible force. FOLLOW THE SATELLITE AS IT IS SUCKED INTO THE VORTEX.
We look through the ripple of warped space-time.  As if holding a lens to one eye, we glimpse two earths at once two identical North Americas.  The two earths turn slightly...

THROUGH the screen door, we are CLOSE ON A MAN'S FACE, staring out... JOHN F. SULLIVAN, 35.  John's eyes tell us needs more than just a shave and a good night's sleep.  T man has demons.  Right now he is LOOKING OUT AT: SAMANTHA TAYLOR, 33.  A knockout.  Dark blonde hair, pier blue eyes.  Not happy.  She jams a suitcase into the back seat of her car and starts back for the house.
So, that's it, Sam?  You're just walking out?
Samantha strides in past John towards a washer/dryer.
I've been walking out for the last six months.  You didn't notice...or care.
She grabs clothes from teh dryer and exits to...
...towards a stairway beyond, John not far behind.
Fine, go ahead and save the whole world, Sam. (sipping his beer) You don't gotta worry about me.
Damn you.  I tried.  But you wouldn't help me.
Samantha steps into the bedroom to an open suitcase and travel bag.  She starts jamming the clean clothes into th suitcase and then begins to close the case and bag.
You're right.  We should've quit a long time ago.
Sam can't hold back anymore - she cries openly.
It's not your fault.  It's mine.  I can't change.  Wish I could, Sam.  But I can't.
And suddenly Samantha's tears turn to anger.
That's not true and you know it.
John has no reply.  All he can do is watch as she takes h stuff and heads for the door.
Goodbye, Chief.

John stands immobilized in the middle of the room.  He lo down and spots a TEDDY BEAR half stuck under a reading ch And then to a photo of him and Sam at a CARNIVAL SHOOTING GALLERY.  Sam's holding the teddy bear.  John turns at th SOUND of the backdoor slamming.  Looks out a window down Samantha getting in her car and driving away.
John enters, goes straight for a half empty bottle of BUSHMILLS IRISH WHISKEY.  As he brings the bottle to his mouth...BRRRRING.  The PHONE.

Swigging Bushmills as he steps to a combination portable phone/answering machine, John takes off his jacket.  We notice two things: an NAPPED DETECTIVE SHIELD and a .38 REVOLVER. BRRIING.  John grabs the phone.
What?  It don't matter, Lady.  Why?... Cause I don't got no friends or family.

BANG.  Slams down the phone.  And stares around the room. WE'VE BEEN IN THIS HOUSE BEFORE -- 29 YEARS AGO.  This wa Frank and Julia sullivan's house.  Time has not been good it.  Furnishings haven't changed much, but the house is missing the warmth it had when a family filled it with lo John's eyes dart to a PHOTOGRAPH next to the desk.  It is picture of THE SULLIVAN FAMILY from back then.  Too many memories.  He grabs his coat, heads out...

The field is EMPTY.  Covered in shadows.  John sits alone the top row of the BLEACHERS, cradling his bottle of BUSHMILLS.  He takes a long pull.  As he stares down at t empty field, his eyes slowly drift over to home plate... AUDIO FLASHBACK: a VOICE rises up out of the darkness.  T voice of memory...
Batting next.  Johnny Sullivan.

We hear the SOUNDS of CHEERING parents.  The CLAPPING, WHISTLING & SHOUTING is hauntingly juxtaposed against the empty playing field and bleachers we see on the screen. CRACK: sound of the bat solidly connecting with the ball. CAMERA follows invisible runner from home to first base.
Sullivan's safe at first.  Batting for Johnny's father is...Coach Newman.
John takes a deep breath, glances from first base back to home plate...then looks off into the distance - a cold thousand yard stare.
John shuffles up the pathway.  The SOUND of a TV - X-FILE filters out from inside the house.
John walks in the front door.  GORDY JR., 8, carrying an overstuffed BLT, whizzes by...
Hi, Uncle John.
John notices smoke filtering out of his kitchen.
I'm not your uncle, kid. (yelling into kitchen) Gordo, what are you doing here?
Sully!  Is that you?
Follow John into the kitchen.
Meet GORDON HERSCH, 35, computer geek, lovable dough boy. Last seen by us in 1969 as a six-year old.
Hey, Sull.  My cable's out again.
What the hell is that smell?
John glances at a mound of burnt bacon dripping on the st
Can you believe Ellen still won't let me cook in the house?  I melt one lousy frying pan, y'know?
Gordy Jr. scoots into the kitchen.
John, guess what?  Dad's taking me fishing.  Wanna come?
Wish I could, Gordy.  But you bring me back a big one.
Hey, OK if Gordy uses your old gear?
I think it's somewhere in the closet... if you can find it.
Gordy Jr. runs out.  O.S. sounds of him rummaging through hall closet.
So Yahoo went up another two points. Man, did we miss the boat on that one.
John puts the Bushmills bottle down, and grabs two Molson
Coulda, woulda, shoulda, pal.
John laughs, hands Gordo a beer, and lights up a cigarett
Sam called Ellen.
John reacts.  Nothing else needs to be said.  A beat, the
Why don't you come with us?  Three days of fresh air and barbecue would do you some good, man.
Dad, John, c'mere...
Gordy Jr. sticks out of the closet, attempting to drag ou large BLACK STEAMER TRUNK, stenciled with yellow letters.
Hey, Gordy, what 'ya doing?
Dad, check it out.  Fire Department!  Can I open it up?

John thinks about it for a second.  Noting the curious gl in little Gordy's face, nods OK. Gordy Jr. pops open the latches, opens the trunk.  Gordo crouches down beside his son, checks out the dusty conten HOLD ON JOHN'S REACTION to what Gordy Jr. finds in the tr
Wow.

Gordy Jr. reaches in and takes out: FDNY HELMET & JACKETS Briefly puts on the enormous helmet, then sets it aside. Reaches back into the trunk and pulls out the disassemble pieces of a 12 gauge SHOTGUN.
Hey!  Gimmie that!

Gordo takes the shotgun from the boy and places it ginger inside the closet. Simultaneously, Gordy Jr. hands off a leather-bound SCRAP to John.  Before John can react, Gordy Jr. lifts up an AMATEUR RADIO TRANSCEIVER.
What's this, Dad?
Powerful memories fill his face.
John, that's your Dad's old ham radio. Remember?  Remember how we used to beg him to let us talk on that thing?
the transceiver and microphone - mint condition 1965 Yaes 101, and a "Silver Eagle" Astatic D-104 microphone.
This is not a toy.
Can we try it Dad, can we try it?
Gordo looks at John.
What the hell.

Glass doors separate the study from the family room.  The RADIO is set on a dusty wooden desk.  Scotch-taped to the of the radio is a diagram for the radio setup and "QSL" cards: certificates from around the world acknowledging "contact" with "WB2YXB" -- FRANK SULLIVAN, BAYSIDE NY. Gordo hooks up the radio.  Gordy Jr. shuts off the TV.
So this was what people used before the Net, huh?
Man, do I feel old.
GORDO TURNS THE RADIO ON.  Shows Gordy how it works.  Gor rotates the tuning dial, nothing but "dead bands."  STATI
It's junk, kid.  Nobody uses those things anymore.
KNOCK.  Front door opens.  John's head turning around.  M ELLEN, 35, Gordo's wife.  The grown-up in the family.
Gordo, do you know what time it is? (a beat) Hi, John.
Ellen.
Ellen notices John's weary look but says nothing.  We get sense she knows what is wrong.
C'mon Gordy, let's go.
Oh, mom...

Gordo and family pour into the yard between the two house John shuffles out behind them.  Gordo and Gordy Jr. quick disappear into their house, but Ellen lingers for a momen looking back at John standing alone.
You all right, John?
Oh, yeah.

Ellen holds her glance for a moment.   John smiles, thinl masking his sadness.  Ellen nods okay, and she is gone. looks up at the stars, then down to the HAM RADIO ANTENNA his roof, now looking raggedy from 29 years of neglect.
TV: LARRY KING is interviewing STEPHEN HAWKING. John is back on the Bushmills.  He races clumsily for the CORDLESS PHONE.  CLOSE ON SPEED DIAL BUTTONS.  John hits
(answering machine voice) Hi, this is Julia.  Please leave a message after the tone.
Hey, Ma, it's me.  Checking in.  Probably at work.  Anyways, I'll see you tomorrow night.  Love you.

John puts down the phone.  Stares at the FDNY trunk.  He stumbles to it.  Sits down and opens it up.  It's filled his Dad's stuff.  He picks up and leafs through the old SCRAPBOOK - PHOTOS and CLIPPINGS illustrate FAMILY HISTOR A quick glimpse of Dad's high school baseball team; Mom a Dad's 60's wedding.

John at his First Communion pictured with his MOTHER - WE SENSE LOSS AND SADNESS IN HIS EYES - THIS BOY LOOKS HURT. A folded newspaper drops out.  John picks it up.  Front p of the DAILY NEWS.  Top half READS: "October 13, 1969. AMAZIN'S TAKE GAME 2 - SERIES EVEN."  The lower half READ
He shoves the paper back in the scrapbook.  Puts the albu down - he can't deal with those wounds.  He glances up at
Is this anomaly connected to the space storm and the NASA satellite that disappeared in 1969?
We don't know.  But given the similarities of their location and appearance, this is a question that merits further investigation.

NOTE:  Larry King's show plays for the duration of this scene. John settles in, takes off his work shirt.  Underneath he on a T-shirt.  We notice a NICOTINE PATCH on his arm. Doesn't stop him from burning another Marlboro.

head_text.subj: JOHN IS SUDDENLY STARTLED BY A NOISE FROM THE STUDY

text: (over radio) CQ 15, here is WB2YXB, by for call.
John gets up, Bushmill bottle in hand, and stumbles into.
CQ 15, come in 15.
Approaching the desk, John sits down at the radio.  Reach out to the mic -- presses down on the red squawk bar.
Uh, hello?
WB2YKXB, who've I got?
(slightly slurred) Name's John.
In the BACKGROUND of FRANK'S VOICE, we barely hear WALTER CRONKITE interviewing someone.
Are you licensed to broadcast, buddy?
Look, I don't really remember how this thing works.
Listen, you can't broadcast without a license.  Unless this is an emergency, you gotta get off the band.
(chuckling) Pal, my whole life's an emergency.
A pause.
Where are you transmitting from?
Queens, New York.
Whatta ya know.  Bayside, born and raised.
I thought these things were for talkin' around the world.
15-band closes down at night.  During the day you can chew the band with China if you want.
I can't believe people are still using these things.
As John releases the squawk bar, the distant sound of Fra TV filters out of the HAM.
Can you hold on a second?
And then John hears the sound of a door closing.
Sorry 'bout that.  So Queens, you psyched for the Series?
(taking a swig) I don't really follow baseball anymore.
What?
I got fed up with all the bullshit.
Fed up?  Lemme tell you something, in a 1000 years, when school kids study America, they're gonna learn about three things: the Constitution, Rock 'n' Roll, and Baseball.
Despite his mood, John has to smile.
How can you live in Queens and not love the Amazin's?
John warms to the topic of his boyhood heroes.
If you're talking The Amazin' Mets, well, that's different.  You know people talk about Seaver, but I'll love Ron Swoboda til the day I die.
Static crackles out over the radio.  The signal weakens.
(through static) I'm right with you, man.  He's got the heart of a lion.  Hey, how 'bout the first game of the Series?
Yeah.  It was all over after Buford nailed Seaver's first pitch outta the park.
More static.
No way, brother.  Ain't gonna happen.
BZZZSSSSHHHH - loud static.  THE SIGNAL IS GONE.
Who the hell was that?
Behind him, on TV, Larry King and Hawking continue talkin

head_text.subj: ANOTHER FINGER PRESSING DOWN ON THE RED SQUAWK BAR... FRA

text: SULLIVAN.  Seated at the polished wooden desk.
Hello, Queens.  You there?

Silence.  The signal is gone.  Frank leans forward, jiggl the frequency dial, trying to regain the signal.  No luck Slightly frustrated, he stands and opens the glass doors the family room where Julia is watching TV - a very young STEPHEN HAWKING is being interviewed by WALTER CRONKITE,
Frankie, Johnny wants to say goodnight.
(a little distracted) Sure.
He starts to take a step into the room, and stumbles over Elvis, sleeping by the door...KNOCKING INTO and CRACKING GLASS PANE in one door.

John, dog tired and more than a little wasted, gets up fr the desk, inadvertently leaving the Ham Radio ON, and shuffles for the family room through the glass doors. CAMERA HOLDS, CLOSE on the GLASS PANE...CRACKED in the ex same spot where Frank knocked into it 29-YEARS AGO.

Frank unpins the police badge from Johnny's shirt, takes whistle from around his neck.  He pulls up the covers and softly kisses Johnny's forehead.  You can tell he loves t kid more than anything in the world.
(lullaby-like) Take me out to the ballgame, take me out with the crowd.  Buy me some peanuts and cracker jack...
John plops down on sofa, half asleep.  The TV drones on.
...I don't care if I never get back.
The LEGEND reads: OCTOBER 11th - FIRST GAME OF THE WORLD SERIES Blue sky.  A SOFTBALL soars into view.  It drops down and into a WILLIE MAYS' style basket catch by Frank Sullivan.

The same Little League field that Frank circled on his Ha yesterday, October 10, 1969.  And the same field at which John sat in the stands drinking last night, October 10, 1 We are in the 9th inning of a friendly SOFTBALL GAME betw the local COPS and FIREMEN.  A lot of NYPD and FDNY T-shi sweats and caps.  Plenty of Mets stuff, too. Having made the catch, Frank coolly pulls the ball from h mitt as he starts running toward the infield diamond. Tagging up at 3rd, sorely tempted to try for home is SATC DELEON, 30, NYPD Detective.  Satch feints for the plate, Frank feints the throw.  For a maddening, gleeful moment, Frank has Satch caught between 3rd and home. In the STANDS, Johnny Sullivan, Marge Hersch and the FAMI of the other ballplayers scream for whomever they want to this game of chicken. On the SIDELINES, Johnny, Gordo and the other KIDS servin BATBOYS and WATERBOYS, jump around in anticipation. At HOME, Butch Foster stations himself to take the throw. Suddenly, Satch fakes to 3rd, then bolts for home.  Frank pegs it to Butch, who tags the sliding Satch.  Game over.
Lucky throw, fire boy.
(jogging in) Luck, my ass.

They square off.  Pretending to fight.  Julia steps betwe them.  And they all descend into laughter. Frank and Satch each wrap an arm around Julia and start o Within a step, Johnny slips in under Frank's other arm.
(to Johnny) See that, kid.  Practice.  Practice.

Close on a TV: PRESIDENT NIXON tosses the first ball to o the 1969 WORLD SERIES. REVERSE to see many of the PLAYERS and FAMILIES from teh softball game are parked around a couple of TVs watching game.  BEER flows from a keg.  SOFT DRINKS are passed aro HAMBURGERS and HOT DOGS are cooking on the BBQ. Satch sits with Johnny and Gordo and some other kids. Frank and Julia tend the BBQ.  Butch brings out some beer A fun day.

A DETECTIVE'S CAR pulls up next to a couple of BLUE & WHI at West 155th St.  The Northern tip of Manhattan Island. Across construction barricades is a half-torn down GREEK RESTAURANT.  Several UNIFORMS can be seen beyond it, look at something on the ground. As John exits the car, the passenger door swings open and MEET a guy we haven't seen in 29 YEARS - SATCHEL DELEON, Shaved head, square jaw.  A ram-rod straight, craggy warr Thirty-plus years on the force now endow him with a rare combination of smarts, guts and sense of humor.
(as they walk) Don't choke on your pride, Sull.  You ain't ever gonna catch another one like that.
She made up her mind.  Nothin' I do is gonna change it.
Nothing you're willing to do.
Spotting John and Satch, a UNIFORM approaches them.  They keep on walking.
What's the story?
Survey crew found a body.  Actually a skeleton.  Over here.

The uniform leads John and Satch around some overgrown we to SEE a patch of freshly unearthed dirt...out of which sticks a HUMAN SKULL and COLLAR BONE. In the B.G., a CRIME SCENE unit can be seen arriving by v
Be real careful when pulling it out.  And get the dirt around it.
As Satch turns to talk to a second UNIFORM and a couple o SURVEYORS, John notices a man raking leaves in a yard not away.  As he starts to him, to Satch:
I think I'll visit the neighbor.
CLOSE ON FRED SHEPARD, 72.  As the scene unfolds, we can the half torn down diner/crime scene through a window.  S oversees the operation. MRS. SHEPARD, 70, hands John a cup of coffee.
Thanks.
John looks out the window.
Used to get breakfast there all the time back from the boat.  Them Greeks were good people.  Once that McDonalds opened up on Dyckman, they lost all their business.

John glances around the room - notes family PHOTOGRAPHS. There's a picture of Shepard in younger days on a commerc fishing boat.  Next to it a faded black and white picture Mrs. Shepard, 35.  A few pictures of the Shepards and the YOUNG SON.  And at the end, a color photograph of the sam son, about 20, in DRESS BLUES, graduating from the Police Academy - CLASS OF '64.
Your son on the job?
Was.  Carl died in the line of duty. October '69.
I'm sorry.
Shepard points to a frame above the fireplace: Distinguis Service Medal, CARL SHEPARD, awarded posthumously.
My boy lived and bled blue.
Silence.  Mr. and Mrs. Shepard stand very still.  John discreetly glances at his watch.

THUNDER in the distance.  CRIME SCENE personnel have made some progress in unearthing the skeletal remains.  A coup of drops of rain tap the ground and the bones. John stands looking down at the skeleton.  A long beat. then he turns to Satch and they start for the car.  Behin them, the skeleton is carefully pulled free from the grou WE SEE its wrists are BOUND with GLASS TAPE.
CHINESE TAKE-OUT CARTONS are placed in a microwave.

the woman holding the cartons: JULIA SULLIVAN, 29 YEARS O than the last time we saw her.  But she looks okay, she l happy. We are in the kitchen of Julia's Upper West Side apartmen It is raining.  We notice THE GEORGE WASHINGTON BRIDGE outside a BAY WINDOW.
(calling out) I thought it'd be nicer to eat here.
Sounds good.
(walking into the other room) I'm sorry Sam couldn't make it.
(lying badly) Yeah, those grad school applications are driving her crazy.
Julia hands John a Coke.  Close on her face - she feels h son's pain.
I'm sure everything'll work out. (beat) She really loves you...
(changing the subject) So how are things at the hospital?
Fine.  You know Dr. Schwartz retired last month?
No kidd'n, he musta been pushing 90!
Close.
Beat.
So how'd you like LION KING?
Oh, I loved it.  I wish you'd gone.
I know.  I'm sorry.  Work.
You work too hard, John.
Look who's talking.
They share a laugh.  And then slowly the laughter dies. John's expression changes as he quietly lights a cigarett Julia knows what he's thinking...
29-years tomorrow.
A long beat.
I wish I could remember him better. Truth is, most of the stuff I know is from the stories you used to tell.  But they're not mine.  They're not my memories.  They're yours.
Julia glances at an old photo of Frank, then back to John
You would have liked him, John.  And he would have liked you.
PING.  The microwave timer sounds off.
Frank's dog, Elvis.  Poking his nose in a carton of Chine take-out on the floor.  An arm drops into frame - scruffs puppy's back.  The Rolex diver's watch tells us the arm belongs to Frank.
Frank sitting at his desk.  He fires up an unfiltered LUC STRIKE, pops a Rheingold.  Next to him a Daily News headl NASA INVESTIGATES SPACE STORM.
...WB2YXB calling unidentified station, Queens.  CQ 15.
(over radio, sounds like he's had a few drinks) Hello?
I been Q-ing you all night.  How the hell did you do it?
Huh?
The World Series.  You called Buford's homer.
Wasn't too tough, buddy.  Game happened almost thirty years ago.
What are you talking about?  I'm talking about this afternoon.
This afternoon?
Frank puts his finger on the squawk bar, about to say something, but just at that moment his son Johnny appears the doorway in his pajamas.
Daddy, come up and sing the baseball.
(to Johnny) I'll be up soon, Little Chief.
John Sullivan's face, thunderstruck.  The camera stays on John.  He puts down his drink.
Sorry 'bout that.
What'd you just say?
Oh, that was my kid.
John looks up at the photo on the wall: FRANK, JULIA AND YEAR OLD JOHNNY SULLIVAN (CIRCA 1969).  A beat, then:
You call your son Little Chief?
Uh huh...
What'd you say your name was?
Frank...Frank Sullivan.
Is this some kind of joke?  Gordo is that you?  Are you fucking with me?
Look pal, I'm just askin' how you...
You're telling me your name is Frank Sullivan, you live in Queens and you just saw the first game of the '69 Series...live?
Right...and I'm asking how you called the game.
Gordo, if this is you, so help me...
What the hell does Gordy have to do with it?
John's POV - top of radio - in FADED PEN, on a piece of masking tape, is written: "WB2YXB"
What'd you say your station...uh, your call letters were?
The call letters hang in the air.  A breath, then...
Now you listen to me.  My name is John Francis Sullivan, I live at 1060 41st, where I've lived my whole life.  And I saw the first game of the '69 Series at my Uncle Butch's house with my father...
What?
29-years ago.
Frank dropping his cigarette in the ashtray.  It rolls ou and lies smoldering on the desk.  He doesn't even notice.
29 years...?

My dad's name was Frank Patrick Sullivan, he was a fire fighter and a die-hard Mets fan.  And every night when I went to bed he sang to me... (softly, almost singing) Take me out to the ball game, take me out with the crowd...
Beat.
What the hell...
I'm dreaming this.  Shit, this is a dream.
I'm not dreaming.
John reaches out to touch the radio.  But he stops, his h hovering just above it.
So you're Frank Sullivan, huh?  It's 1969 and you're sitting at your desk in the study, just chewin' the rag?
He smells smoke, sees the cigarette burning a hole in the desk.  Spooked, Smokey the Bear just started a fire.
Christ!
Frank beats out the flame with the newspaper.
What's going on?
(lying) Nothing...I just spilled something.

head_text.subj: A DISTINCTIVE BURN SCAR GRADUALLY MORPHING ONTO JOHN'S DE

text: John pushes the Bushmills to the side, staring at the sca It hits him - hard.
Oh my god.
What?
You just burned the desk.
What's happening?
John rubs his fingers over the old burn scar.
You burnt the desk...I can see it.
Eerie quiet, the only sound is the rain outside John's window.
That's impossible.
What if it's not...
reaching out, touching the radio.
Dad...?
Johnny...?
Shockwave.  A long moment of absorption.  INTERCUT Frank John.
How could this be happening?
I don't know.
We gotta be bouncing off the mother sun spot of all time.
Sun spot?
Yeah, that's how Hams work.
Wait a sec...there was something on the news.  Something about this space anomaly.  I think they said it was connected to some storm in '69.
Frank glances at DAILY NEWS HEADLINE - SPACE STORM.  He s nothing for a long beat, struggling to understand.
You sound...ground up...?
I'm thirty-five years old.
Thirty-five?  That would make it...
Frank pulls back from the radio...
1998...?  This is wrong.  Who are you? Why are you doing this?
I'm not doing anything. (beat) Look, I don't know what's going on.  But I swear on my life, I"m here at your old desk, on your Ham, in our house, right now...in 1998.
John's voice has a conviction that Frank cannot deny.
It's really you, isn't it?
Yeah...I think so.
Silence.  Both men trying to wrap their minds around the reality of the situation.  Slowly accepting.
Thirty-five?  Jesus, you're almost as old as I am... (long beat) What's your life like?  You married?  Got kids?
Beat.
No, not yet.
Too busy playin' ball, huh?
Nah, I gave it up.
Johnny gave up baseball?
You happy?
John takes a sip, the answer caught in his throat.
You're still my Little Chief, right?
I'm trying to be, Dad.  I'm tyrin'. (pausing) It's good to hear your voice. (quiet beat) I missed you...so much.
Quiet beat.  A burst of static crackles the air.
(re: static) What's that?
I think I'm losing you.
No wait, don't go!
It's okay.  I'm still here, Chief.
But you're not...you're not still here.
More static.  The signal breaks up, then returns weaker.
What are you talking about?
I lost you.
What?
I never knew you, Dad.
Why?
Fire.
On the job?

It was an abandoned warehouse - hit by lightening. (beat) Butch told Ma it was just one wrong turn. Said it wasn't your fault.  You went with the training, with your instincts. (beat) If you'd just gone left instead of right, you would've made it.
That can't be...that's not gonna happen.
It did, Pop.  It did.
When?
October 12, 1969.
Heavy static now.  They can barely hear each other.
But that's tomorrow.
(fully realizing) Tomorrow.  Jesus...it hasn't happened. It doesn't have to happen.
Both men frantic.  Their words overlapping...
Don't go.  Don't go in that warehouse...
I don't understand.
Final blast of static.  The SIGNAL is GONE.  The BAND is GONE.
Moonlight casts a glow over the sleeping Johnny.  Frank s in and stands looking down at him.
John crawls out a window, through the rain, onto the roof

Rusted Ham radio antenna, half-fallen over. John scoots over to it, straightening it.  But he slips, sliding down the roof, coming to rest against the chimney A light pops on from an upstairs window across the street Gordo appears in the window.  Does a double take when he John, sitting on the roof, soaked, drunk.
(sliding open window) Sull!  What the hell!
I talked to him Gordo.  I talked to my Dad.
Gordo's heart starts to break.  His best friend has slipp over the edge.
C'mon, man.  Get inside.  I'll come over. We'll play some Nintendo.
No.  I gotta tell him the address, so he doesn't go in.
Go in where?
The warehouse.  Buxton seeds.  It's tomorrow.
I know pal.  I remember.  Twenty-nine years tomorrow.
The LEGEND reads: OCTOBER 12th - SECOND GAME OF THE WORLD SERIES
BLACK CLOUDS, EARTH SHATTERING THUNDER.  A massive BOLT O LIGHTNING rockets out of the menacing sky STRIKING THROUG WINDOW on the 3rd floor of the warehouse.  A FIRE BEGINS.

GAME 2 plays on TV.  Butch, Gibson and the rest of the un sit around enjoying the game.  A very distracted Frank st watching from the doorway to the kitchen. We are in the bottom of the 9th with the Baltimore Oriole Brooks Robinson coming to the plate.
Oh, man. Robinson is gonna nail it and we're gonna be dead.

SUDDENLY THE ALARM SOUNDS, moving the groaning firemen reluctantly to action, and freezing Frank in surging anxi Gibson is up and passing Frank...who begins to move like in a trance. A RAPID MONTAGE of Frank, Butch and the others readying t head out.  Gibson grabs a little TRANSISTOR RADIO.
Let's move it, gentlemen...three alarm. Lit up abandoned warehouse.  West 49th.
Frank looks like he's going to throw up.
John, lost in thought, rounds a corner towards the bar.

The LADDER & ENGINE trucks barrel out of the firehouse. As SIRENS SCREAM, Frank and Gibson secure themselves into position.  Gibson excitedly switches on his radio to the game.  He notes that Frank is not the least bit into it.
Sully, you cool?
Frank seems not to hear him.
Frank.  Hey, man.  You alright?
I'm alright, Gibby.

From the RADIO we HEAR the last play of the game as Brook Robinson grounds out 3rd to 1st.  METS WIN!  CHEERS are h in the streets and from the CABS of the racing fire truck Gibson whoops it up.  Frank barely acknowledges the win.
John moves through the crowd of cops - ad lib greetings - slides into a booth occupied by Satch and Gordo.
How you feeling?
Better.
You get your roof fixed?
John shoots a look at Gordo, who quickly changes the subj
Can you believe it, Yahoo goes up another point today...

Located off the East River in lower Manhattan.  The 9th Battalion Fire trucks are first on the scene.  A couple o GREEN & WHITES are already there, uniform cops keeping a onlookers at a safe distance. FLAMES shoot out from the 4th and 5th FLOOR WINDOWS. Starting to lick their way up to the 6th floor and roof. SMOKE billows out of the windows on the 3rd and 2nd floor Lighter smoke spirals out from the door on the 1st floor. Frank, Gibson and other firemen under Butch's command tak stock of the situation and start to deploy. HOSES are run from HYDRANTS to the PUMPER TRUCKS. The LADDER is swung into position for an assault on the r
Bastard's moving fast.
Thank God it's abandoned. (to the men) Surround and drown...nobody goes in.

Frank nods in agreement.  Directly above them, another BO OF LIGHTNING CRACKS through the darkening sky. A death shudder creeps up Frank's spine.  And for the fir time in his life, Frank Sullivan is SCARED SHITLESS. Frank stares up at the sky, transfixed.  THUNDER punches sky with a huge roar.  RAIN starts to fall. And in the distance, as if from inside the burning buildi a FAINT SCREAMING is first heard, and growing louder.
Hear that?
What?
Suddenly, out of the building runs a STONED TEENAGE GIRL screaming and babbling incoherently.
Help!  Help!  Oh, god.  Help.  She's up there.  She's trapped!  Please!
Immediately galvanized, Frank moves to the girl.
Hey, hey.  It's gonna be okay.  We're gonna help.  Okay?   Okay.
She starts to calm down.
Now tell me, who's up there?
My girlfriend, Molly.
Where?
In a room...an office...or something.  We live there.  Top floor.  Something fell on her.  I couldn't help her.  Please, you gotta...gotta...
Frank looks to Butch.  A beat.  Butch gives him the nod. Frank and Gibson gear up and go.
You realize that if you'd bought a thousand dollars worth of Yahoo in '96, it'd be worth fifty-grand today?
You doin' okay, John?
Tough day, you know.
Satch and Gordo nod in sympathy.  Gordo raises his glass. Satch and John follow.  A yearly ritual.
To your dad.
To my dad.

Frank and Gibson step into the warehouse.  Butch behind t Flames haven't reached this area yet, but the ROAR of the fire above them is deafening, and smoke billows down THE STAIRWAY before them.  They sprint towards it and start u ONE FLOOR.  TWO FLOORS.  THREE FLOORS, and suddenly they face to face with a WALL OF FIRE blocking access to the 4 floor. Frank and Gibson stop and stare into the inferno.
It looks open on the other side.
Don't know what's behind it.
One way to find out.

And he barrels through the line of fire onto the 4th floo Gibson starts to do the same when the 5th floor gives way above Frank, sending burning timber and debris cascading around him and cutting off Gibson's route. Now Frank's only way to go is up the stairs toward the 5t floor.  He turns to Gibson.  Coming up behind him is Butc Across a gulf of flames Frank yells and waves at them to the hell out.  And then suddenly, part of the 3rd floor around Gibson and Butch starts to go.
(screaming over fire) Get out...while you still can...
Frank turns and bolts for the 5th floor as a huge flaming BEAM CRASHES down onto the stairway behind him, forcing Gibson and Butch to scramble like hell back down the stai
(soft) ...it's not your time.

Fire fighters are efficiently and expertly hard at it. Running out lines.  Extending ladders.  Moving a FIRE BOA into place - all communicating via walkie-talkies all on same frequency. The BIG LADDER is now in place.  As it telescopes up, the ROOF MAN, BILL CAWLEY, begins his climb. PUMP TRUCKS and THE FIRE BOAT keep pumping water onto the blaze.  But no matter.  For the moment, this is one OUT O CONTROL NIGHTMARE FIRE.
Frank reaching the 5th floor.  It's an inferno.  He keeps moving, tearing up the stairs for the 6th floor.
(over walkie) Gotta be another way up, Frank.
(into walkie) Then fuckin' find it. (heading in) I'm going for the girl.
(over walkie) Billy, you better get up top.
ROOF MAN edges up the ladder, as it telescopes above him.
This is Billy, Frank. I'm on my way. South side.
(reaching 6th floor) Glad to hear it.  See you on top.

FIRE has torched OPEN a GAPING HOLE IN THE ROOF. Frank peers around through the smoke and fire and rain. he sees, huddled in the temporary saftey of the corner of OFFICE, but trapped by a fallen CONDUIT, the GIRL, passed from smoke inhalation.
(into walkie) I've found the girl.
Frank dashes into the office and heaves the conduit off t girl.  He hoists her over his shoulder and heads out.

Butch and Gibson exit the warehouse past the HOSE CREW already working its way into the building. They look up to the top of the warehouse where the LADDER haltingly inching its way up the side of the building.

The fire on this floor is now a raging inferno.  Flames s up from the stairway below through the open roof.  Surrou by fire, Frank, carrying the girl, strides for what looks like a WINDOW on the south side of the floor.
(into walkie) It's real hot in here, Billy.  I'm coming out quick.
But apprehension rips across Frank's eyes as he reaches t window and looks down to see.
The top end of the ladder FROZEN some 10 FEET BELOW THE WINDOW.  BETWEEN WALKIE-TALKIES.
I'm jammed up here, Frank!
Oh mother...
Butch and Gibson are now by the base of the LADDER TRUCK which is near the canal side of the building.  Butch scre at the ladder OPERATOR.
What the fuck, GINO!  Tell me!
Gear box cracked, Butch.  We're fucked.
(into walkie) Frank!  Frank!
I know, Butch.  I know.

Frank clicks off the walkie-talkie and turns to survey th hell around him.  The STAIRWAY IS GONE. To the RIGHT is a DOOR, flames around it, but none coming from the room beyond it. To the LEFT, another DOOR, a metal one, this one surround by fire - flames licking out all around it from room beyo EASY CHOICE.  Frank turns, heads towards DOOR ON THE RIGH No.  Wait.  HE STOPS.  SOMETHING'S WRONG.  HEART POUNDING

head_text.subj: WE HEAR JOHN'S WORDS ECHO IN FRANK'S HEAD

text: ...one wrong turn... (beat) If you'd just gone left.
And for the first time in his life, Frank Sullivan goes against his instincts and his training as he... TURNS BACK AROUND AND GOES THE OTHER WAY.
Gordo is in the middle of a story when...
...principal calls us in 'cause Gordy hacked into the school system - sent out a little X-rated e-mail. (nervous laughter) Scary, huh?  Eight-years old.
Just keep him away from girls.
...something happens - TIME STUTTERS AND REPEATS:
(repeat) Just keep him away from girls.

The effect is like a phonograph needle stuck in the groov It lasts only a second and nobody seems to notice.  Nobod except John, who looks wildly disoriented.  He grabs hold the edge of the table as if to keep his equilibrium. John breaks into a cold sweat.  His HEART POUNDING AWAY.

Franks reaches the door on the LEFT.  White heat and flam shoot everywhere...A FUCKING FURNACE.  He tires to open i IT'S LOCKED!  WHAM!  Frank kicks at it.  WHAM!  WHAM!  Th door blows open and flames leap out, the energy of the bl tossing Frank and the unconscious girl back onto the floo fire surging over their heads.  But then... He sees something on the other side of the doorway, insid the room, on the far wall.: A SMALL METAL SWINGING DOOR.

Frank cradles the girl.  Gets down on his knees, crawling under the heat.  Reaching the SWINGING DOOR.  Pushes it o revealing: A smooth metal SPIRAL SEED BAG CHUTE. Frank rips open his jacket and bundles the girl to him. works himself and the girl onto the top of the chute. The ROOM BEGINS TO SHAKE.  BRICKS TUMBLE OUT OF THE WALL. The whole GODDAMN BUILDING is going to COLLAPSE. Frank lurches forward until he and the girl start to move down the chute.

As Frank and the girl plunge through the bowels of the inferno...large portions of the building begins disintegrating around them...a giant storm of BRICKS, MOR METAL AND BURNING WOOD biting their tails... Gaining speed through each up-rushing floor...5-4-3-2...F and the girl zoom down towards the END OF THE SLIDE only find IT'S BOARDED UP.  OH SHIT! Frank grips the girl tight, raises his BOOTS, bends his knees, and like a HUMAN BATTERING RAM, SMASHES THROUGH TH

THEY'RE AIRBORNE.  Frank and the girl.  Floating in SLOW MOTION out over the CANAL and landing in the water betwee the WAREHOUSE DOCK and the FIREBOAT. A YELL snaps Butch's and Gibson's attention to what is happening.  Gibson starts running for the CANAL, ripping his coat and hat before leaping into the water.  But Fran getting pulled down by his fire tank and the weight of th girl.  Finally, Gibson reaches him, taking the girl.  Fra quickly sheds his jacket and the tank. Butch stands watching on the dock.  He takes a moment to close his eyes in thankful prayer.
You okay, man?
(starting to giggle) Elvis has left the building.

Hitting the water has shot the girl back to consciousness look passes between her and Gibson.  A look he won't forg SILENCE.  Then the thunderous SOUND of the WAREHOUSE CAVI IN on itself, sending flames shooting high into the sky. Frank lies back, floating on the water, the rain pelting around him, letting the miracle of it all, take him over.
(soft) Little Chief.

It happens again.  Time stutters and repeats.  As if the sprockets were caught in the projector. CRASH!  The GLASS SHATTERS AGAIN!  CRASH...CRASH... Camera ratchets into the exploding storm of the flying gl ice and whiskey.  And then time stops as we hold close on frozen shard - in it, the cracked reflection of John's ey The camera moves through the reflection and into.

A burst of light and then...distorted images.  Like looki at reflections through a smashed mirror.  The cracks gel, we are in... MONTAGE.  A SERIES OF QUICK FLASHING IMAGES. 1969: Frank, Johnny, Butch and Satch at the World Series. 1971: Johnny and Gordo sitting on Frank's lap, at the Ham 1972: Frank and Johnny, playing catch. 1976: Johnny winning a swimming race at Longbranch Boys C Frank cheering. 1984: Frank, Julia and Satch beaming with pride as John graduates from the police academy. These images appear as DISJOINTED FRAGMENTS OF NEW MEMORI A PAST THAT DIDN'T EXIST BEFORE.  A past where Frank Sull didn't die in that fire. It's like watching random frames from the Sullivan Family 8mm home movies as John's brain struggles to absorb decad of NEW MEMORIES in the span of seconds.
Normal vision slowly returning.  The broken glass is rock on the table.
John.  John, you all right?
(a whisper) Longbranch...?
What?
John doesn't respond.
You're not looking too good.
Whoa, I just...I just...
What is it?
Beat.
My father didn't die in a fire?
Huh?
My father didn't die in a fire?
Fire?  What are you talking about?  He had cancer, John.
Cancer.  It was the cigarettes.  Right? The cigarettes?
Yeah, lung cancer.  Ten years ago.
His hand shaking, John takes a long sip of his beer.  Gor and Satch exchange a concerned look.
Maybe you outta lay off a little...
Gordo, I wasn't dreaming.  I talked to him, it was real.
Huh?
The Ham radio.  That's how come he didn't die in the fire.
A loaded silence.  Three guys looking at each other, thin very different things.
(into radio mic) Johnny?  Johnny?  You there?  C'mon, Chief, answer me...
Nothing but static.  Frank jiggles the frequency dial.
Chief? (louder) Chief, are you there?
Silence.  And then a voice...
I'm right here, Daddy.
Frank turns.  Johnny, sleepy faced, wrapped in his blanki stands just outside the room - he looks a little scared.
It's okay, Chief. (beat) C'mere.
Johnny shuffles over, Frank lifts him up on his knee - brushes the hair out of his face...and gets an idea.
Streetlights flood the tree-lined street.  Frank & Johnny standing next to the little red bicycle.
Okay, partner, whatta you say we tame this bronco.
Johnny's eyes: SHAME & FEAR - doesn't want to disappoint father again, but too scared to get on the bike.  Frank reaches out, holds Johnny's hand.
I'm scared.
Don't be scared.  This time I'm right behind you if you fall.
Daddy, Daddy, I can't.
No, but we can.  We can do it together. Spirit and guts, Chief.
A long beat.  Johnny takes a deep breath, nods OK, slowly getting on the bike.  Frank's holding on to the seat.
Take your time.  I'm not gonna let go 'til you say okay.
Johnny takes a gulp of air, starts pedaling.  Slowly movi forward.  The bike picks up some speed.
You ready?
Wait...
I'm right here behind you...
Frank's still running alongside, holding on to the seat.
Okay!
Frank lets go.  Johnny keeps pumping those little six-yea old legs.  A bit wobbly at first, but he's gonna make it. Johnny's eyes: determination & self-confidence.
(clapping) Yes!  That's it!  You got it, you got it! Way to go, Chief!
I'm doing it!  I'm doing it!
The proud father.
(under his breath) Atta boy.
Johnny blissfully riding around Frank in a big gentle cir Frank slowly spins around keeping his eyes on his Little Chief.

John walks in the front door, takes off his coat... The house looks different.  Cleaner, furnishings less rag John moves through his home, taking in the subtle changes He reaches the study.  And there, beside the desk, is something that makes him stop: A PHOTOGRAPH on the wall beside the desk -- FRANK, JULIA FOURTEEN YEAR-OLD JOHNNY SULLIVAN.
Oh my God...

The picture changed.  John aged from 6 to 14.  Julia's hairstyle and clothes changed from 60's to 70's.  Frank's hair receded and grayed.  Jon is staring at evidence of a history that didn't exist before. John grabs the old family scrapbook he found in Frank's trunk.  Opens it, unfolds "FIREMAN KILLED" CLIPPING. The main headline still reads: "OCTOBER 13, 1969.  AMAZIN
But the sub headline now reads: "FIREMAN RESCUES RUNAWAY

John turns, stares at the radio questioningly.  He starts sit down at the desk when he spots something on the front edge of it.  WORDS CARVED INTO THE WOOD, 29 YEARS AGO by fighter Frank Sullivan.  The day John saved his father's life: I'M STILL HERE CHIEF The last letter is missing.  But then a patch of wood sta to morph - as if it were being carved by an invisible kni A BURST OF STATIC.  RADIO CRACKLES TO LIFE.
(through radio) ...can you hear me?
One hand on the squawk bar, the other holds the jack-knif is using to finish carving the letter F.
(through radio) Dad...?
Chief?!  Is that you?
Yeah, it's me.
You're the voice of an angel, Johnny.  If you hadn't told me, no way I would'a ever made it.
Frank cuts himself off in mid-sentence.
Dad, you there?  You okay?
Yeah.  I'm okay. (beat) What about you?  I want to know.  About you.  And your mom.
John hesitates for a moment.  Lights up a smoke.
We're doing all right, Dad.  We're doing good.
Tell me.
It's hard to explain.  Something happened today.  It was like a dream.  And when I woke up I had all these new memories. Good times.  Times we never had before.
I'm glad.
But John looks troubled.  Something bothering him.  He ta a hit off his cigarette.
Dad, I gotta tell you this...cause you should know.  Cause I still remember.
What, Johnny?  What is it?
What it was like when you died in the fire...

Both men are silent for some moments.  The hum of static. breath, then -- JOHN (cont'd) We needed you.  I needed you.  So many times...I wished for you.  But you weren't there for me. (beat) Mom tried.  But she was hurting.  I used to hear her, every night, for years, crying herself to sleep.
Frank grips the radio mic, stunned.
I didn't think...
The static grows.  John leans into the mic
Well, you think about it.  And you remember, cause I don't wanna lose you again.  I don't ever want Mom...
John's voice cracks, choking back the tears.
(over static) You won't.  I swear to God you won't.  I love you, son.
A blast of static.  The signal is gone.  It is quiet. John leans back.  Takes a breath.  Reaches out for the ph CLOSE ON PHONE'S THREE SPEED DIAL BUTTONS. John HITS #3.
(through answering machine) Hi, this is Julia.  Please leave a message after the tone.
Ma, it's me.  Call me.  We gotta talk.
As John slowly hangs up the phone, something catches his Something that wasn't there yesterday. LONGBRANCH BOYS' CLUB SWIMMING TROPHY...A GREAT SUMMER.

Through several glass windows a CLOCK READS: 11:52 PM. Julia and other medical personnel are working on a heart attach victim and they are winning.  She is in charge and is impressive.  Cool...efficient...expert. A sixth sense causes her to look up to see: FRANK. Standing behind the windows.  Motionless.  Gazing at his wife. Julia holds on him for a split second, concern and surpri etching across her face.  She turns back to her work, the says something to another ER nurse, who nods okay.  Satis the patient is out of the woods, she peels off her gloves heads for the door.
Julia steps through the door as Frank approaches.
Frank...what's wrong?
Nothing.  I just wanted to see you.
He takes her in his arms, snuggling his head against her neck, losing himself in the scent of her hair. FRANK (cont'd) (whisper) I'm not goin' anywhere, Jules.  For the rest of your life.
It's hard to tell, we can't see his face, but it looks li Frank is crying.
Frankie, what is it?
But Frank is silent.  So they just stand there, holding e other.  And then Julia notices the burn and scrape marks Frank's arms and neck. JULIA (cont'd) I got a bad feeling today...I was worried.
I'm here.  Bruised but not broken.
Frank pulls his head back, looks into his wife's eyes and kisses her on the mouth.  It's a long kiss. As they come up for air.
Where's Johnny?
I tucked him in at Gordo's.
You give him his drops?
One in each ear. (beat) What would you do without me?
Probably marry some rich doctor and never have to work...

Julia sees something through a glass door that stops her short.  A YOUNG INTERN is standing over a gurneyed PATIEN The YOUNG INTERN is changing the I.V. BAG. JULIA (cont'd) What's he doing?  Frank, I gotta...
He knows she's back on the job.  Waves "no problem."
Julia interrupts the Young Intern as he hooks up the bag.
Excuse me doctor, is that Benazepril?
Yes.
Julia quickly shuts off the I.V.
I gave this patient 50 mills of Benedryal on admittance. (unhooking I.V. bag) Mix them and he's dead.
Why wasn't I made aware?
It's in his chart.

The intern steps back: "Oh shit."  Julia takes charge. The patient stirs: a SCRAGGLY HIPPIE, looks kind of like Pacino in SERPICO.  A breathing mask covers his bearded f Barely conscious, his eyes focus on Julia. After a quick double check of the patient, Julia looks up Through the glass door she can see Frank watching.
(mouthing to words) I love you, Bud.
(mouthing back) I love you more.
The clock on the wall now reads: 12:01 AM. And the LEGEND reads: OCTOBER 13th - WORLD SERIES TRAVEL DAY
MEN and WOMEN, standing and sitting, seen only from teh w down.  All wearing dark cloths and speaking in hushed voi A recognizable VOICE?  The edge of a CASKET?  A NIGHTMARE
John is bathed in SWEAT.  He twists to CAMERA and his eye pop open.  A glazed, confused look pours out of them. SEE past an empty bottle of BUSHMILLS on the night stand clock READS 12:01 AM.

THE NIGHTMARE REPEATS - like some horrible instant replay MEN and WOMEN, standing and sitting, seen only from the w down.  All wearing dark clothes and speaking in hushed voices.  FLASHES OF FACES SWIMMING INTO THE POV...indisti blurring into each other.  Is that UNCLE BUTCH?  SATCH?

A terrified and disoriented John stumbles out of bed.  He moves to the bathroom.  But he stops.  Something is wrong The bedroom has changed.  It looks like a DUMP. John shakes his head, trying to blink away the nightmare. But the room does not change back.  He goes to teh bathro Splashes his face.  He looks up to the mirror and...
The same horrible instant replay.  Flashes of faces swimm into the POV...

He is CROUCHED UNDER A TABLE.  STARING AT THE CASKET.  Al Bewildered.  Crying. A MAN, seen only from teh waist down, approaches the tabl As he crouches down his face drops into the frame.  It is FRANK.  His face etched in a terrible pain.

The kitchen looks different: dirtier, uncared-for.  John looks different too: like a guy on the tail end of a life bender.  He cracks open a Bushmills.  Pours a couple of s into his instant coffee.  Several sips to settle his nerv He reaches for the cordless phone and HITS SPEED DIAL #3.
Noah's Deli.  Can you hold?
Confused, John clicks down the receiver.  His hand is sha as he punches the speed dial button for the second time.
Noah's Deli.
On the slam of John's phone, we got to...

John knocks on the door.  It opens to reveal a Jamaican w clutching a crying infant, a toddler hanging off her leg. Behind them we half recognize Julia's apartment.  We know it's her apartment because of the BAY WINDOW and the view THE GEORGE WASHINGTON BRIDGE.  But everything else is different.  Different furniture.  Different pain job. John stands speechless.  The Jamaican woman regards him..
Can I help you?
(relaxed) I'm looking for Julia Sullivan.
I think you have the wrong apartment.
But this is her place.  910 Riverside. Apartment 3C.
I'm sorry, but no one by that name lives here.
John just stands there, lost, questioning his grip on reality.  Liquor on his breath, fear in his eyes, he is a scary sight.  Jamaican woman does the smart thing - she s the door.

ON SATCH, scavenging the fridge while absorbed in some papers. Through the open door he SPOTS JOHN across the squad room Even at that distance, Satch can see John's unsteady walk fucked up demeanor.  Satch's eyes go to stone.
John leans over the sink, wet paper towels pressed to his face.  He barely reacts to the SOUND of the door.  He doe react to the silence that follows.  Satch stands in the doorway...looking him over.
What?
A long silence.
Another rough night, huh?  That it?
Yeah.  That's it.
John moves for the door.  But Satch grabs him, slams him against the wall.  Startled, John freezes.
Do not disrespect me.  Disrespect yourself all you want.  But not me.  Or anybody else around here.  You got that?
John shrugs, sagging against the wall.
This is getting real old, John.  And I'm tired up to here with it...
I'm sorry.  I just...you know...I...

And I'm tired of the I'm sorrys.  I don't need 'em.  What I need is a partner I can count on. (pause; softens) I care about you.  Not cause of me and your old man.  Not cause of your mom. But because of you.
Satch steps back.  An awkward beat.
We got the preliminary forensics on that skeleton. (opening door to the squad) Your gonna want to look at it.

Satch and John approach their adjoining desks.  Satch sli an 8X10 PHOTO off the top of an OLD YELLOWED POLICE FILE hands it to John.  It is a picture of the skeleton discov behind the Greek Diner.  But what catches John's attentio what picks at his subconscious, is the decaying GLASS TAP binding the wrists.
Bad memories... (re: photo) You imagine the odds...us diggin' up a Nightingale Murder?
John looks from the photo to the file on Satch's desk.  I reads: NIGHTINGALE MURDERS.  John slowly sinks into his chair.
She makes ten.
Ten?  No.  I remember this case.  Three. He killed three women.
What're you talking'?  You know better than anybody, John.  You've read this file a thousand times.

John fixes on the file.  Then slowly reaches for it.  It' filled with police and forensics reports.  And PHOTOS.  C scene shots of 9 DEAD WOMEN.  Linked by TWO gruesome deta they were all GARROTED, wrists bound with GLASS TAPE. John turns over the last PHOTO and his heart stops...his universe crashing down on him.
No.
Julia is at the door watching Frank tuck Johnny in.  John wears his Mets' cap and cradles his baseball glove.  He's that exhausted/excited kid moment before sleep sets in.
(very soft) Buy me some peanuts and cracker jack...I don't care if I never get back...
Johnny's eyes close.
Boy is he excited about the game tomorrow.
He ain't the only one.
Marvin Gaye plays from the HI-FI.  Frank grabs a beer, as Julia comes in -- putting on her coat while taking her ke from a hook.  She's wearing her nurse's uniform.
I'm off.
(turning to her) Wish you weren't.
(stepping to him) Do you know how much I love you?
Frank takes her in his arms.  Starts to move her to the music.
Yeah, actually I do.
They kiss.  And dance.  And kiss.  And dance.  He starts slip her coat off.  She laughs and wriggles away from him Naughty boy.  And she is out the door.

John pulls in past SAMANTHA'S CAR as she comes out the ba door with the Teddy Bear and other stuff she left behind. John gets out of his car, clutching the 'Nightingale' fil his eyes are red, swollen by tears and booze.
John, are you all right?
The answer is no.  He looks terrible, as haunted as any m could possibly be.  He doesn't mean to, but he snaps --
What are you doing here?
Samantha jumps, frightened.
Ellen said you were working.  I just wanted to pick up the rest...
John turns, lost and ashamed.  Sam walks to her car and starts to cry.

John enters, plunks the Nightingale file on the desk.;  H stares at the FAMILY PHOTOGRAPH on the wall. JULIA IS MISSING.   A look of loss in Frank and John's fa John fingers the Nightingale file.  A nightmare. He hits the ANSWERING MACHINE BUTTON to hear Samantha's halting message.  As that plays...
John steps to teh counter and pours himself a stiff Bushmills.  Turns and steps back into...

John collapses in the chair.  Stares at the words carved the desk - I'M STILL HERE CHIEF.  He rubs his fingers ove the smooth carving...his eyes going to the radio. A quiet moment.  John slowly puts his hand on the squawk, leans into the mic...
Dad, you there?  Can you here me? (silence) Dad?  I need you to be there.
A long beat.  The hum of static.  And then...
(through radio) Right here, Chief.  Sorry I lost you last night.  Damn thing keeps cutting out.
Dad...Dad... There's... I need to...
Are you alright"?
(sipping Bushmills) Something happened, something...
What?  Johnny, what's wrong?
It's Mom.
What?  What is it?
She's not here.
Whatta you mean she's not here?
She...she died.  It's like it just happened.
She just died, your mother just died?
No Dad, it happened a long time ago, a long time ago for me.
A dreadful moment of silence.
When?
October 22, 1969.
Jesus Christ...that's...ten days from now. (beat) How?
Silence.
Johnny, I gotta know.
Long beat.  You could hear a fuckin' pin drop.
She was murdered.
Eerie silence as John's words hang in the air.
Murdered?  Why?
There was this case.  A serial.  He murdered three women, all nurses, between '68 and '69.  The papers called them the Nightingale Murders.  They never caught him.  But the killings just stopped.
What kinda twisted animal.
Dad, we did something.  Something to make it worse.
Whatta you mean...
He didn't just kill three women anymore. He killed ten.
What are you talking about?

Something we did changed the case...changed history. (beat) Mom wasn't dead.  But then after you didn't die in the fire something must have happened.  And this guy, this Nightingale guy, he kept on killing...it was like a spree...seven more women.
I gotta take her away, John.  I'm gonna take your mother away.  He can't hurt her if I take her away.
I don't know... (beat) What about the other women?
I'll warn them.
That'll never work.  They'll just think you're crazy.
What can we do?  You don't even know who this guy is.
No.  Nobody got... (realizing) Wait a minute.  I might not know who he is, but I know where he's gonna be.  I got the case file.  We know what he's gonna do before he does it.
So what should I do?  Call the police? You think they'll believe me?
They will if they catch him in the act. You can make that happen, Dad.  You can tail the victim and call it in at just the right moment.
I don't know, John.  I'm a fire fighter. This is...this is different.
I do know.  I'm a cop.  This is what I do.
John takes a long sip from the Bushmills.

You ever talk to a victim's family?  The one's left behind?  They don't act like what you'd think.  There's panic and fear.  But mostly, it's like there's this logic problem.  And if they could only solve it, everything would be okay. (a breath) But if you look real close - look at their eyes - you can see it.  Just a glimmer.  But somewhere they know.  They know their world is never gonna be the same.
What if the radio stops working?  Christ, what if I can't reach you again?
Then you get Mom the hell out.  But Dad, those other women weren't supposed to die.  We don't try to stop this guy, we're gonna live with that for the rest of our lives.
Frank takes a deep breath, swallows some air.
What do I gotta do?
John grabs the THICK YELLOWED POLICE FILE.  Opens to homi report on Karen Reynolds.  CLOSE ON FORENSIC PHOTO

The next victim was Karen Reynolds...It happens tomorrow. (reading) Case file says she left St. Vincents at six.  Show'd up at Cozy's Bar around six thirty.  She walked outta that bar around seven-thirty.  They found her dead in an empty lot behind the place at eight o'clock.
Frank jots down teh info.
Why not just get the cops to watch the bar?

They'll question her.  Whatever they tell her could change what happens. (beat) No, I want you to follow her.  See if anybody's watching her, hittin' on her. I'm betting somebody's gonna walk outta that bar with her.  When they do, you call the cops.
Close on NIGHTINGALE FILE on John's desk.  Zoom in on the date below KAREN'S HOMICIDE PHOTO: October 14, 1969. The LEGEND reads: OCTOBER 14th - 3RD GAME OF THE WORLD SERIES
A woman waits to pay for a mini pack of Kleenex and some KAREN REYNOLDS.  A wool coat over her Nurse's uniform. Frank's and John's voices continue over the scene.
What do I tell them?
Tell 'em there's a homicide in progress... cause by the time they show up there will be.

As Karen moves to the cash register, the CAMERA WIDENS TO REVEAL FRANK, awkwardly pretending to read a magazine. Frank readies to follow her when he suddenly trips over a crate of vegetables and goes down on one knee. Karen looks in the direction of the accident, and for a s second, her eyes lock with Frank's.  Embarrassed, Frank l away as he rights himself. Frank edges out of the grocery store as Karen steps into street and dodges traffic towards a corner BAR/RESTAURANT the end of the block, past a heavily overgrown VACANT LOT Frank follows Karen across the street and finds himself, as Karen enters the bar, at a point near the murder site described by John.  He pauses to stare at it.

Frank enters the place.  Sort of a singles atmosphere, bu comfortable one.  It's HAPPY HOUR.  On the TV, the Mets' Hodges offers his analysis of Game 3. Frank looks about, down the bar and into an area with boo and tables.  A few folks at the bar.  A group of YOUNG WO laughing in a booth.  But NO KAREN REYNOLDS.  Frank's blo runs cold in a spasm of panic when...
Hey, Chuck.
Hey, Karen.

Frank wheels around just as Karen passes him from teh LAD ROOM.  There is the trace of a bump, enough for Karen to note of Frank.  Ad lib EXCUSE ME.  She then starts moving down teh bar towards the booth of young women. Frank checks out everyone in the bar, not knowing quite w he's looking for. Karen slips into the booth with her friends.  Ad lib HELL Frank orders a beer, but his eyes are fixed on the booth. Karen and a friend take note of Frank staring at them. Embarrassed, he turns away, checking his watch: 6:40PM. at just that moment a SCRAGGLY MAN passes by, taking a se at the end of the bar.  We have seen this man before.
Satch and a YOUNG DETECTIVE stand at the sinks, washing u
Is that really how you got the Son of Sam?  Parking tickets?
Satch shrugs a yes.  Wipes his hands and heads out into t squad.  The Young Detective follows.
John's at his desk.  Keeps glancing at the phone, fiddlin with the NIGHTINGALE FILE... A PHOTOGRAPH OF KAREN REYNOL Satch passes John on his way to the coffee machine.
Any word on our bones?
John shakes his head no.  Young Detective joins Satch at coffee machine.  John overhears:
But how'd you think of it?
You're pulling over with a .44 bulldog tucked in your pants getting ready to blow somebody's brains out...I  figure the last thing you're thinking about is alternate side of the street parking.
Young Detective nods, impressed.  John is less impressed.
That's what we need here, Satch.  A lucky break.
That wasn't luck, Johnny boy.  That was smarts and ten plus on the job.
BOTTLE OF RHEINGOLD drops into frame next to half empty o
From the girls, pal.  All of 'em.

Frank glances at the women in the booth.  They're all loo at him, smiling.  A big one from Karen. His watch says 7:05.  Taking the new bottle, Frank steps the bar, past the Scraggly Man and walks to the booth. Charmingly shy, Frank is kind of at a loss for words.
I was, uh, I'm not really...
(noting Frank's jacket) Fireman, huh?
(noting wedding ring) A married fireman.
Oh, what the hell.  Have a seat.  What's your name, fireman?
Frank.
And Frank takes a seat, sliding in next to Karen.  An awk moment for him as she takes a closer look at his face.
Do I know you?
I don't think so.
(puts it together) From the Korean market up the street. (laughing) Mr. Lee make you pay for those veggies.
You following her, Frank?  You're not some kind of stalker or something?
I follow fires, nothing else.
General laughter all around.

John has a CORKBOARD set up next to his desk.  On it he h arrayed several photos of the Nigthingale victims under t dates of their murders.  He looks over at the photos, the the forensics photo of Karen Reynolds on his desk.  BRRIN John shoots a look at the wall clock.  It reads: 7:45.
(grabbing the phone) Sullivan. (beat) You're kiddin'... (grabbing pen; scribbling)
Satch is alerted by John's sudden burst of energy.
Mario, you are the best...right, right, right.  Spell it out for me.
At the bar, the Scraggly Man stares at Frank and the wome Franks checks his watch as he tells a story.  It's 7:50.
Yeah, it was a close call, but...
Close!  The news said it was a miracle you guys got out alive!
Close is just close if you're still alive to talk about it, y'know/
The women around him are clearly enraptured. In B.G. - at the bar - the Scraggly Man, looking frustrat slides off his stool and strides out of the place.
John hangs up the phone.  Satch looks at him, "Whatta we got?"
Our lucky break.  Mario ID'd the dental. Mary Finelli...reported missing April 16, 1968.
(looking at corkboard) April 16...?  That means she was the first.
Which means he probably knew her.
This case just got hot.  We pull on this string...

But for some strange reason John has stopped listening to Satch.  Something else has got his full attention.  It is Nightingale file that lays open on his desk.  It is changing...Karen Reynolds' forensic photo disappears. In everything about her, all evidence of her murder - police reports, photos, witness reports - is GONE. John's eyes shoot to the corkboard.  The head shot of Kar Reynolds and the date of her murder are also GONE.  John looks between the file and the board.
(whisper) Dad...
Frank and Julia stand on the porch, eyes on Johnny - up p bedtime, proudly riding his bike up and down the street.
(a stretch and a yawn) I think I'm gonna head up, take a shower. (slight smile) You wanna tuck the monster in and join me?
Frank doesn't take the bait.
What's the matter?
Beat.
There's something I gotta take care of. Something I need to tell you about.
Okay...
I've been talking to this...guy...this cop...on the HAM...and, uh, he...
Honey, what is it?  Just tell me.
I've been talking to Johnny...on the radio.
I know.  He loves that thing.
No.  Not our Johnny.  I mean, it's Johnny...but not now...in the future.
It takes her a moment to absorb what he just said.  And t she gets it... he's talking about a game.
Sounds like fun.
She kisses him on the forehead and heads into the house.
I'll be upstairs...if you want to play.
I'm serious.
So am I.
A quiet beat.  And then...
(over static) Karen Reynolds is alive and well.  We did it, Dad.
We are now...
(over the HAM) I'll be damned.
Did you see him?  Do you know who he is?
No.  I just kept talking to her. (beat) There was a lot of guys in that bar - could'a been any of 'em.
It's okay.  This is working.  This is gonna work.
Whatta we do now?

(consults file) Sissy Clark, 190 Riverside Dr., apartment 3C.  Tomorrow. (skimming file) She's a nursing student.  Paying her way as a cocktail waitress at the Peppermint Lounge, on west 63rd.  Left work at two A M...killed in her apartment, between two thirty and five.
Frank jots down the info.  Fires up a Lucky.
Got it.
Dad, I think I may be able to get you enough information to make sure the DA can nail this bastard.
How?

Coupla days ago they dug up a body in Washington Heights - Mary Finelli.  Girl disappeared in '68.  Turns out she was his first kill.  Which means he probably knew her.  Most serials know their first victim.  I'm gonna do some checking - see if I can put any of this together...
All right, I'm with you. (beat) I just hope we know what the hell we're doing.
A soft burst of static.  The signal returns a little fuzz
Tell me something good, Chief.  Tell me about the future.
(lighting up a Marlboro) Well they found out cigarettes give you lung cancer.
